Yes, we have a winner! That's right, folks, there was a solution to that incredibly difficult puzzle last week, and
three people found it. Richard Lockwood, Michael Gotts and the team of Alan and Richard Macksey had correct
answers. Since it was a tie, the judges decided that the Macksey team won, on the basis of Neatness (as was specified),
and also due to the insane amount of information they provided. Arrangements will be made for the delivery of the
prize, and the Mackseys should contact the News-Letter for further details.
However. Gotts and Lockwood should be rewarded for their efforts, and indeed they shall be: they should stop by
our office on Thursday evening for a free beer.
As for the puzzle itself, a few notes: Several portions of the puzzle disappeared or were mangled in the numerous
typings they went through, despite the valiant efforts of David Hawk, master typist, and the author. Notably, the
absence of XTRNY6LSN from the Blake. There was also a question of the punctuation, but it war. consistant as

higher and higher
The recently announced tuition rise at the medical school
above and beyond the rise slated for other University
divisions indicates an unfortunate change in a long-standing
,University policy of maintaining tuition at all divisions on an.
equal level.
Apparently mandated by economic necessity, the new
enactment has still drawn the scorn of top financial experts
at Hopkins. Vice-president for Business Management Robert
Bowie expresses the fear that the med school tuition hike
could well serve to inhibit cross-fertilization among the
divisions of the University. True, it is not clear at this point if
students from other divisions will be allowed to continue to
take courses at the med school without falling prey to
similarly larger fees. But even if tuition remains at the lower
rate for cross-over students, ill-feelings could well be the
product of some students paying a higher rate for the same
instruction.
Despite the University's claim that tuition at the School of
Medicine has "inappropriately" been held down in the past,
it appears that advantage is being taken of med students who,
with future employment virtually assured, are not likely to
be too vociferous in their complaints. After all, they can take
out more loans, right?
